evidence: Alloy Nb0.25 shows yield strength of 748 MPa, fracture strength of 843 MPa and ductility of 14.2%. With the decrease of Nb content (i.e., Nb0.2), the fracture strength and plasticity appreciably increase to 983 MPa and 31.8%, respectively. Nevertheless, the yield strength decreases to 607 MPa.

microstructure: dual-phase structure of HCP and BCC
evidence: The as-cast Nb0.2 alloy assumes a dual-phase structure of HCP and BCC, which is consistent with the EBSD and XRD results.

The HEA containing the highest amount of Nb (i.e., Nb0.25) has a stable BCC lattice structure, and no stress-induced transformation occurred. The corresponding work-hardening rate (Fig.  1b ) shows a continuously decreasing trend, which is attributed to dynamic recovery and indicates a dislocation-slip-dominated plastic deformation mechanism  [24] . Different from other typical brittle BCC HEAs  [11, 12] , Nb0.25 exhibits relatively ductile deformation behavior with a fracture strain of 14.2%, which might be interpreted from the point of the VEC (valence electron concentration) criterion proposed previously  [32] , i.e., the VEC of Nb0.25 is 4.13, less than the upper limit for ductile HEAs (i.e., 4.4).

With the decrease of the Nb concentration (i.e., Nb0.2), a dual-phase structure consisting of BCC and HCP was formed. Compared with HfTa0.5TiZr, the fracture strength (983 MPa) and plasticity (31.8%) of Nb0.2 are further increased due to the addition of Nb.

When the Nb content is further decreased (i.e., Nb0.15), formation of the HCP is facilitated at the expense of BCC during solidification (Fig.  2 ). The work hardening rate in the latter part of stage III shows a slow decline behavior until zero, rendering the fracture strength and plasticity to 1003 MPa and 25.8%, respectively.

Finally, Nb0 alloy with no Nb addition consists of a single stable HCP phase. Hence, a high yield strength (≈1206 MPa) and fracture strength (≈1315 MPa) but very limited plasticity (≈4.1%) were obtained, as shown in Fig.  1a .

Decreasing the Nb content reduces the BCC phase stability and promotes the martensitic transformation from BCC to HCP upon loading. Moreover, additional mechanical twinning in the product HCP phase was also activated due probably to the lower SFE resulted from the Nb addition, giving rise to an enhanced sustained strain hardening rate and thus a superior combination of strength (983 MPa) and uniform ductility (>26%), which surmounts the level of most BCC refractory HEAs reported previously.
